Shakespeare's works structurally distinct, but it cannot capture the beauty of
the sentiments and emotions they express, or why they affect us the way they do. At least, not yet.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What are some other uses of stylometry aside from resolving Shakespeare's identity?
Options: A. Measuring the beauty of Shakespeare's works, B. Testing whether an email is spam or not, C. Memorizing passages of Hamlet, D. Predicting who will win a sports championship
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who is often quoted as saying, "Some are born great, some achieve greatness, and others have greatness thrust upon them"? Options: A. William Shakespeare, B. Francis Bacon, C. Christopher Marlowe, D. Wincenty Lutosławski Correct Option: None
Question 2: What do some people speculate about William Shakespeare? Options: A. That he was a famous playwright from the 19th century, B. That he was a pseudonym for another writer or a group of writers, C. That he only wrote tragedies, D. That he was a prominent politician Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the name of the Polish philosopher who formalized the method of stylometry in the late 1800s? Options: A. Wincenty Lutosławski, B. William Shakespeare, C. Francis Bacon, D. Christopher Marlowe Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the primary goal of stylometry? Options: A. To investigate questions of literary authorship, B. To analyze the beauty of sentiments and emotions in poetry, C. To determine the date of an ancient text, D. To identify plagiarism in academic works Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is an example of a characteristic that stylometry examines to determine a writer's style? Options: A. Average sentence length, B. Use of metaphors, C. Number of characters in a play, D. Historical context of the work Correct Option: None
Question 6: What statistical concept is used to measure the tightness of data points in stylometry? Options: A. Variance, B. Standard deviation, C. Mean, D. Median Correct Option: None
Question 7: What tool is used to reduce the multidimensional space of characteristics into simple principal components? Options: A. Principal Component Analysis, B. Cluster Analysis, C. Regression Analysis, D. Factor Analysis Correct Option: None
Question 8: According to stylometric analysis, who is believed to have collaborated with Shakespeare on "Henry VI," parts one and two? Options: A. Francis Bacon, B. Christopher Marlowe, C. William Shakespeare alone, D. Unknown Correct Option: None

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
You and a fellow castaway
are stranded on a desert island playing dice for the last banana. You've agreed on these rules: You'll roll two dice, and if the biggest number 
is one, two, three or four, player one wins. If the biggest number is five or six, 
player two wins. Let's try twice more. Here, player one wins, and here it's player two. So who do you want to be? At first glance, it may seem 
like player one has the advantage since she'll win if any one 
of four numbers is the highest, but actually, player two has an approximately
56% chance of winning each match. One way to see that is to list all
the possible combinations you could get by rolling two dice, and then count up 
the ones that each player wins. These are the possibilities
for the yellow die. These are the possibilities 
for the blue die. Each cell in the chart shows a possible
combination when you roll both dice. If you roll a four and then a five, we'll mark a player two 
victory in this cell. A three and a one gives 
player one a victory here. There are 36 possible combinations, each with exactly the same 
chance of happening. Mathematicians call these
equiprobable events. Now we can see why 
the first glance was wrong. Even though player one 
has four winning numbers, and player two only has two, the chance of each number 
being the greatest is not the same. There is only a one in 36 chance
that one will be the highest number. But there's an 11 in 36 chance 
that six will be the highest. So if any of these 
combinations are rolled, player one will win. And if any of these 
combinations are rolled, player two will win. Out of the 36 possible combinations, 16 give the victory to player one,
and 20 give player two the win. You could think about it this way, too. The only way player one can win is if both dice show 
a one, two, three or four. A five or six would mean 
a win for player two. The chance of one die showing one, two,
three or four is four out of six. The result of each die roll 
is independent from the other. And you can calculate the joint 
probability of independent events by multiplying their probabilities. So the chance of getting a one, two, 
three or four on both dice is 4/6 times 4/6, or 16/36. Because someone has to win, the chance of player two winning
is 36/36 minus 16/36, or 20/36. Those are the exact same probabilities
we got by making our table. But this doesn't mean 
that player two will win, or even that if you played 36 games
as player two, you'd win 20 of them. That's why events like dice rolling 
are called random. Even though you can calculate 
the theoretical probability of each outcome, you might not get the expected results
if you examine just a few events. But if you repeat those random events
many, many, many times, the frequency of a specific outcome,
like a player two win, will approach its theoretical probability, that value we got by writing down 
all the possibilities and counting up the ones for each outcome. So, if you sat on that desert island
playing dice forever, player two would eventually 
win 56% of the games, and player one would win 44%. But by then, of course, the banana
would be long gone.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: To calculate joint probability of independent events, you _____ their probabilities.
Options: A. Multiply, B. Divide, C. Subtract, D. Add
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: In the game described, what numbers on the dice result in a win for player one? Options: A. 1, 2, 3, or 4, B. 2, 3, 4, or 5, C. 3, 4, 5, or 6, D. 1, 3, 5, or 6 Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is the approximate chance of player two winning each match? Options: A. 44%, B. 50%, C. 56%, D. 60% Correct Option: None
Question 3: How many possible combinations are there when rolling two dice? Options: A. 20, B. 25, C. 36, D. 40 Correct Option: None
Question 4: What term do mathematicians use to describe events with the same chance of happening? Options: A. Independent events, B. Equiprobable events, C. Random events, D. Theoretical probabilities Correct Option: None
Question 5: Why does player two have a higher chance of winning despite having fewer winning numbers? Options: A. Because the chance of each number being the greatest is the same, B. Because the chance of each number being the greatest is not the same, C. Because player one has more winning combinations, D. Because player two has more winning combinations Correct Option: None
Question 6: How many combinations result in a win for player one? Options: A. 14, B. 16, C. 20, D. 22 Correct Option: None
Question 7: How can the joint probability of independent events be calculated? Options: A. By adding their probabilities, B. By subtracting their probabilities, C. By multiplying their probabilities, D. By dividing their probabilities Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the chance of getting a one, two, three, or four on both dice? Options: A. 12/36, B. 14/36, C. 16/36, D. 18/36 Correct Option: None
Question 9: What happens to the frequency of a specific outcome when random events are repeated many times? Options: A. It decreases, B. It increases, C. It remains the same, D. It approaches its theoretical probability Correct Option: None
Question 10: If the game were played many, many times, what percentage of games would player two eventually win? Options: A. 40%, B. 44%, C. 50%, D. 56% Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 7. 

This question has the same intent as the ground truth MCQ, which is to determine how the joint probability of independent events can be calculated. The options provided in Question 7 are also similar to those in the ground truth MCQ, with the correct answer being "By multiplying their probabilities" (Option C), which matches the correct option in the ground truth MCQ (Option A: Multiply). 

Therefore, the index of the most similar generated MCQ is 7.

a one, two, three or four. A five or six would mean

would be long gone.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: You are more likely to approach theoretical probability of expected results, if a random event is _____.
Options: A. Done one time only, B. Independent, C. Repeated over and over many times, D. Non-random
Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 3

**Transcript**:
You and a fellow castaway
are stranded on a desert island playing dice for the last banana. You've agreed on these rules: You'll roll two dice, and if the biggest number 
is one, two, three or four, player one wins. If the biggest number is five or six, 
player two wins. Let's try twice more. Here, player one wins, and here it's player two. So who do you want to be? At first glance, it may seem 
like player one has the advantage since she'll win if any one 
of four numbers is the highest, but actually, player two has an approximately
56% chance of winning each match. One way to see that is to list all
the possible combinations you could get by rolling two dice, and then count up

for the yellow die. These are the possibilities 
for the blue die. Each cell in the chart shows a possible
combination when you roll both dice. If you roll a four and then a five, we'll mark a player two 
victory in this cell. A three and a one gives 
player one a victory here. There are 36 possible combinations, each with exactly the same 
chance of happening. Mathematicians call these
equiprobable events. Now we can see why 
the first glance was wrong. Even though player one 
has four winning numbers, and player two only has two, the chance of each number 
being the greatest is not the same. There is only a one in 36 chance
that one will be the highest number. But there's an 11 in 36 chance 
that six will be the highest. So if any of these 
combinations are rolled, player one will win. And if any of these 
combinations are rolled, player two will win. Out of the 36 possible combinations, 16 give the victory to player one,
and 20 give player two the win. You could think about it this way, too. The only way player one can win is if both dice show 
a one, two, three or four. A five or six would mean 
a win for player two. The chance of one die showing one, two,
three or four is four out of six. The result of each die roll 
is independent from the other. And you can calculate the joint 
probability of independent events by multiplying their probabilities. So the chance of getting a one, two, 
three or four on both dice is 4/6 times 4/6, or 16/36. Because someone has to win, the chance of player two winning
is 36/36 minus 16/36, or 20/36. Those are the exact same probabilities
we got by making our table. But this doesn't mean 
that player two will win, or even that if you played 36 games
as player two, you'd win 20 of them. That's why events like dice rolling 
are called random. Even though you can calculate 
the theoretical probability of each outcome, you might not get the expected results
if you examine just a few events. But if you repeat those random events
many, many, many times, the frequency of a specific outcome,
like a player two win, will approach its theoretical probability, that value we got by writing down 
all the possibilities and counting up the ones for each outcome. So, if you sat on that desert island
playing dice forever, player two would eventually 
win 56% of the games, and player one would win 44%. But by then, of course, the banana
would be long gone.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
You and a fellow castaway
are stranded on a desert island playing dice for the last banana. You've agreed on these rules: You'll roll two dice, and if the biggest number 
is one, two, three or four, player one wins. If the biggest number is five or six, 
player two wins. Let's try twice more. Here, player one wins, and here it's player two. So who do you want to be? At first glance, it may seem 
like player one has the advantage since she'll win if any one 
of four numbers is the highest, but actually, player two has an approximately
56% chance of winning each match. One way to see that is to list all
the possible combinations you could get by rolling two dice, and then count up 
the ones that each player wins. These are the possibilities
for the yellow die. These are the possibilities 
for the blue die. Each cell in the chart shows a possible
combination when you roll both dice. If you roll a four and then a five, we'll mark a player two 
victory in this cell. A three and a one gives 
player one a victory here. There are 36 possible combinations, each with exactly the same 
chance of happening. Mathematicians call these
equiprobable events. Now we can see why 
the first glance was wrong. Even though player one 
has four winning numbers, and player two only has two, the chance of each number 
being the greatest is not the same. There is only a one in 36 chance
that one will be the highest number. But there's an 11 in 36 chance 
that six will be the highest. So if any of these 
combinations are rolled, player one will win. And if any of these 
combinations are rolled, player two will win. Out of the 36 possible combinations, 16 give the victory to player one,
and 20 give player two the win. You could think about it this way, too. The only way player one can win is if both dice show 
a one, two, three or four. A five or six would mean 
a win for player two. The chance of one die showing one, two,
three or four is four out of six. The result of each die roll 
is independent from the other. And you can calculate the joint 
probability of independent events by multiplying their probabilities. So the chance of getting a one, two, 
three or four on both dice is 4/6 times 4/6, or 16/36. Because someone has to win, the chance of player two winning
is 36/36 minus 16/36, or 20/36. Those are the exact same probabilities

are called random. Even though you can calculate

if you examine just a few events. But if you repeat those random events

like a player two win, will approach its theoretical probability, that value we got by writing down

win 56% of the games, and player one would win 44%. But by then, of course, the banana
would be long gone.

is independent from the other. And you can calculate the joint 
probability of independent events by multiplying their probabilities. So the chance of getting a one, two, 
three or four on both dice is 4/6 times 4/6, or 16/36. Because someone has to win, the chance of player two winning
is 36/36 minus 16/36, or 20/36. Those are the exact same probabilities
we got by making our table. But this doesn't mean 
that player two will win, or even that if you played 36 games
as player two, you'd win 20 of them. That's why events like dice rolling 
are called random. Even though you can calculate 
the theoretical probability of each outcome, you might not get the expected results
if you examine just a few events. But if you repeat those random events
many, many, many times, the frequency of a specific outcome,
like a player two win, will approach its theoretical probability, that value we got by writing down 
all the possibilities and counting up the ones for each outcome. So, if you sat on that desert island
playing dice forever, player two would eventually 
win 56% of the games, and player one would win 44%. But by then, of course, the banana
would be long gone.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which player has a better probability of winning out of the 36 possible combinations of rolls?
Options: A. The turtle, B. Player 1, C. Player 2, D. The chance of winning is equal since this is random.
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: In the game described, what numbers on the dice result in a win for player one? Options: A. 1, 2, 3, or 4, B. 2, 3, 4, or 5, C. 3, 4, 5, or 6, D. 1, 3, 5, or 6 Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is the approximate chance of player two winning each match? Options: A. 44%, B. 50%, C. 56%, D. 60% Correct Option: None
Question 3: How many possible combinations are there when rolling two dice? Options: A. 20, B. 25, C. 36, D. 40 Correct Option: None
Question 4: What term do mathematicians use to describe events with the same chance of happening? Options: A. Independent events, B. Equiprobable events, C. Random events, D. Theoretical probabilities Correct Option: None
Question 5: Why does player two have a higher chance of winning despite having fewer winning numbers? Options: A. Because the chance of each number being the greatest is the same, B. Because the chance of each number being the greatest is not the same, C. Because player one has more winning combinations, D. Because player two has more winning combinations Correct Option: None
Question 6: How many combinations result in a win for player one? Options: A. 14, B. 16, C. 20, D. 22 Correct Option: None
Question 7: How can the joint probability of independent events be calculated? Options: A. By adding their probabilities, B. By subtracting their probabilities, C. By multiplying their probabilities, D. By dividing their probabilities Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the chance of getting a one, two, three, or four on both dice? Options: A. 12/36, B. 14/36, C. 16/36, D. 18/36 Correct Option: None
Question 9: What happens to the frequency of a specific outcome when random events are repeated many times? Options: A. It decreases, B. It increases, C. It remains the same, D. It approaches its theoretical probability Correct Option: None
Question 10: If the game were played many, many times, what percentage of games would player two eventually win? Options: A. 40%, B. 44%, C. 50%, D. 56% Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 6 and Question 10, however Question 6 does not have the correct options to match the ground truth MCQ. 

The correct answer is Question 10: If the game were played many, many times, what percentage of games would player two eventually win? Options: A. 40%, B. 44%, C. 50%, D. 56% 

This question has the same intent as the ground truth MCQ, which is to determine the probability of player two winning. The options in Question 10 also match the content of the ground truth MCQ, with option D (56%) being the correct answer.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Beneath your ribs, you'll find,
among other things, the pancreas, an organ that works a lot 
like a personal health coach. This organ controls your sugar levels
and produces a special juice that releases the nutrients from your food to help keep you 
in the best possible shape. The pancreas sits just 
behind your stomach, an appropriate home, as one of its jobs
is to break down the food you eat. It aids digestion by producing 
a special tonic made of water, sodium bicarbonate, and digestive enzymes. Sodium bicarbonate neutralizes 
the stomach's natural acidity, so these digestive enzymes 
can perform their jobs. Lipase breaks down fatty substances, protease splits up proteins, and amylase divides carbohydrates
to create energy-rich sugars. Most of those nutrients then get absorbed
into the blood stream, and go on to enrich the body. While all this is happening, the pancreas
works on another critical task, controlling the amount 
of sugar in your blood. It achieves this with the hormones 
insulin and glucagon, which are produced in special cells
called the Islets of Langerhans. Having too much or too little sugar
can be life threatening, so the pancreas must 
stay on constant alert. After a big meal, the blood often
becomes flushed with sugar. To bring us back to normal,
the pancreas releases insulin, which makes the excess sugar 
move into cells, where it's either used 
as an energy source, or stored for later. Insulin also tells the liver
to shut down sugar production. On the other hand, if blood sugar is low, the pancreas releases 
a hormone called glucagon that tells the body's cells and liver
to release stored sugars back into the bloodstream. The interplay between insulin and glucagon
is what keeps our sugar levels balanced. But a faulty pancreas can no longer 
coach us like this, meaning that this healthy 
balance is destroyed. If it's weakened by disease, the organ's ability to produce insulin
may be reduced, or even extinguished, which can trigger the condition
known as diabetes. Without regular insulin release,
sugar steadily builds up in the blood, eventually hardening the blood vessels
and causing heart attacks, kidney failure, and strokes. The same lack of insulin deprives cells
of the energy-rich sugar they need to grow and function. People with diabetes also tend to have
higher levels of glucagon, which makes even more sugar circulate. Without this internal health coach,
our sugar levels would go haywire, and we wouldn't be able 
to digest important nutrients. But like any coach, it's not the pancreas' job 
alone to keep us healthy. It needs our conscious participation, too.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Pancreatic juice contains:
Options: A. Sugars and salts, B. Salts, C. Enzymes, D. Water, sodium bicarbonate, and digestive enzymes
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary function of the pancreas in the human body? Options: A. To produce red blood cells, B. To control sugar levels and aid digestion, C. To filter waste from the blood, D. To regulate body temperature Correct Option: None
Question 2: What is the name of the special juice produced by the pancreas to release nutrients from food? Options: A. Pancreatic acid, B. Digestive tonic, C. Sodium bicarbonate, D. None of the above Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the role of sodium bicarbonate in the digestive process? Options: A. To break down proteins, B. To neutralize the stomach's natural acidity, C. To divide carbohydrates, D. To absorb nutrients into the bloodstream Correct Option: None
Question 4: Which enzyme breaks down fatty substances in the digestive process? Options: A. Protease, B. Lipase, C. Amylase, D. Glucagon Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the name of the special cells that produce the hormones insulin and glucagon? Options: A. Islets of Langerhans, B. Pancreatic cells, C. Digestive cells, D. Endocrine cells Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the function of insulin in the body? Options: A. To increase blood sugar levels, B. To decrease blood sugar levels, C. To aid digestion, D. To regulate body temperature Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the function of glucagon in the body? Options: A. To decrease blood sugar levels, B. To increase blood sugar levels, C. To aid digestion, D. To regulate body temperature Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the condition known as diabetes caused by? Options: A. A faulty liver, B. A faulty pancreas, C. A faulty heart, D. A faulty kidney Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the result of a lack of insulin in the body? Options: A. Sugar levels decrease, B. Sugar levels increase, C. Digestion improves, D. Body temperature regulates Correct Option: None
Question 10: Why is it important for the pancreas to regulate sugar levels in the body? Options: A. To prevent heart attacks, B. To prevent kidney failure, C. To prevent strokes and maintain overall health, D. All of the above Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 3: What is the role of sodium bicarbonate in the digestive process? However, the options provided in this question do not exactly match the ground truth MCQ.

A closer match is not found in the provided generated MCQs as none of them specifically ask about the composition of pancreatic juice. However, based on the information provided in the transcript, Question 2 is the closest in terms of content. It mentions a "special juice" which is referred to as "pancreatic juice" in the ground truth MCQ.

But if we were to choose an MCQ that best matches the intent of the ground truth MCQ, it would be Question 2, since it talks about the "special juice" produced by the pancreas.

However, I must note that the options provided in Question 2 do not match the ground truth MCQ. If I had to choose an index, I would choose Question 2, but with the caveat that the options do not exactly match.

Index: 2

among other things, the pancreas, an organ that works a lot 
like a personal health coach. This organ controls your sugar levels
and produces a special juice that releases the nutrients from your food to help keep you 
in the best possible shape. The pancreas sits just

can perform their jobs. Lipase breaks down fatty substances, protease splits up proteins, and amylase divides carbohydrates

alone to keep us healthy. It needs our conscious participation, too.

among other things, the pancreas, an organ that works a lot

is to break down the food you eat. It aids digestion by producing 
a special tonic made of water, sodium bicarbonate, and digestive enzymes. Sodium bicarbonate neutralizes

can perform their jobs. Lipase breaks down fatty substances, protease splits up proteins, and amylase divides carbohydrates

Beneath your ribs, you'll find,
among other things, the pancreas, an organ that works a lot 
like a personal health coach. This organ controls your sugar levels
and produces a special juice that releases the nutrients from your food to help keep you 
in the best possible shape. The pancreas sits just 
behind your stomach, an appropriate home, as one of its jobs
is to break down the food you eat. It aids digestion by producing 
a special tonic made of water, sodium bicarbonate, and digestive enzymes. Sodium bicarbonate neutralizes 
the stomach's natural acidity, so these digestive enzymes 
can perform their jobs. Lipase breaks down fatty substances, protease splits up proteins, and amylase divides carbohydrates
to create energy-rich sugars. Most of those nutrients then get absorbed
into the blood stream, and go on to enrich the body. While all this is happening, the pancreas
works on another critical task, controlling the amount 
of sugar in your blood. It achieves this with the hormones 
insulin and glucagon, which are produced in special cells
called the Islets of Langerhans. Having too much or too little sugar

Question 7: What is the function of glucagon in the body? Options: A. To decrease blood sugar levels, B. To increase blood sugar levels, C. To aid digestion, D. To regulate body temperature Correct Option: None
Question 8: What is the condition known as diabetes caused by? Options: A. A faulty liver, B. A faulty pancreas, C. A faulty heart, D. A faulty kidney Correct Option: None
Question 9: What is the result of a lack of insulin in the body? Options: A. Sugar levels decrease, B. Sugar levels increase, C. Digestion improves, D. Body temperature regulates Correct Option: None
Question 10: Why is it important for the pancreas to regulate sugar levels in the body? Options: A. To prevent heart attacks, B. To prevent kidney failure, C. To prevent strokes and maintain overall health, D. All of the above Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 5. 

This question asks about the special cells that produce the hormones insulin and glucagon, which is similar to the ground truth MCQ that asks where glucagon and insulin are made. The correct option in Question 5 is A. Islets of Langerhans, which is the same as the correct option in the ground truth MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Today when people complain about the state of American politics, they often mention the dominance of the Democratic and Republican Parties, or the sharp split between red and blue states. But while it may seem like both of these things have been around forever, the situation looked quite different in 1850, with the Republican Party not yet existing, and support for the dominant Democrats and Whigs cutting across geographic divides. The collapse of this Second Party System was at the center of increasing regional tensions that would lead to the birth of the Republican Party, the rise of Abraham Lincoln as its leader, and a civil war that would claim over half a million lives. And if this collapse could be blamed on a single event, it would be the Kansas-Nebraska Act of 1854. The story starts with the Missouri Compromise of 1820. To balance the number of slave states and free states in the Union, it allowed slavery in the newly admitted state of Missouri, while making it off limits in the remaining federally administered Louisiana Territory. But compromises tend to last only as long as they're convenient, and by the early 1850s, a tenacious Democratic Senator from Illionis named Stephen A. Douglas found its terms very inconvenient. As an advocate of western expansion, he promoted constructing a transcontinental railroad across the Northern Plains with an eastern terminus in Chicago, where he happened to own real estate. For his proposal to succeed, Douglas felt that the territories through which the railroad passed, would have to be formally organized, which required the support of Southern politicians. He was also a believer in popular sovereignty, arguing that the status of slavery in a territory should be decided by its residents rather than Congress. So Douglas introduced a bill designed to kill two birds with one stone. It would divide the large chunk of incorporated land into two new organized territories: Nebraska and Kansas, each of which would be open to slavery if the population voted to allow it. While Douglas and his Southern supporters tried to frame the bill as protecting the political rights of settlers, horrified Northerners recognized it as repealing the 34-year-old Missouri Compromise and feared that its supporters' ultimate goal was to extend slavery to the entire nation. Congress was able to pass the Kansas-Nebraska Act, but at the huge cost of bitterly dividing the nation, with 91% of the opposition coming from Northerners. In the House of Representatives, politicians traded insults and brandished weapons until a Sargent at Arms restored order. President Pierce signed the bill into law amidst a storm of protest, while Georgia's Alexander Stephens, future Confederate Vice President, hailed the Act's passage as, "Glory enough for one day." The New York Tribune reported, "The unanimous sentiment of the North is indignant resistance." Douglas even admitted that he could travel from Washington D.C. to Chicago by the light of his own burning effigies. The political consequences of the Kansas-Nebraska Act were stunning. Previously, both Whigs and Democrats had included Northern and Southern lawmakers united around various issues, but now slavery became a dividing factor that could not be ignored. Congressmen from both parties spoke out against the act, including an Illinois Whig named Abraham Lincoln, denouncing "the monstrous injustice of slavery" in an 1854 speech. By this time the Whigs had all but ceased to exist, irreparably split between their Northern and Southern factions. In the same year, the new Republican Party was founded by the anti-slavery elements from both existing parties. Although Lincoln still ran for Senate as a Whig in 1854, he was an early supporter of the new party, and helped to recruit others to its cause. Meanwhile the Democratic Party was shaken when events in the newly formed Kansas Territory revealed the violent consequences of popular sovereignty. Advertisements appeared across the North imploring people to emigrate to Kansas to stem the advance of slavery. The South answered with Border Ruffians, pro-slavery Missourians who crossed state lines to vote in fraudulent elections and raid anti-slavery settlements. One northern abolitionist, John Brown, became notorious following the Pottawatomie Massacre of 1856 when he and his sons hacked to death five pro-slavery farmers with broad swords. In the end, more than 50 people died in Bleeding Kansas. While nominally still a national party, Douglas's Democrats were increasingly divided along sectional lines, and many Northern members left to join the Republicans. Abraham Lincoln finally took up the Republican Party banner in 1856 and never looked back. That year, John C. Fremont, the first Republican presidential candidate, lost to Democrat, James Buchanan, but garnered 33% of the popular vote all from Northern states. Two years later, Lincoln challenged Douglas for his Illinois Senate seat, and although he lost that contest, it elevated his status among Republicans. Lincoln would finally be vindicated in 1860, when he was elected President of the United States, defeating in his own home state, a certain Northern Democrat, who was finally undone by the disastrous aftermath of the law he had masterminded. Americans today continue to debate whether the Civil War was inevitable, but there is no doubt that the Kansas-Nebraska Act made the ghastly conflict much more likely. And for that reason, it should be remembered as one of the most consequential pieces of legislation in American history.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Before 1854, slavery was banned from remaining Louisiana Purchase territory under the terms of ________.
Options: A. The Compromise of 1850, B. The Northwest Ordinance of 1787, C. The 1820 Missouri Compromise, D. The Wilmot Proviso
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the primary reason behind the collapse of the Second Party System in the United States? Options: A. The dominance of the Democratic Party, B. The rise of the Republican Party, C. The Kansas-Nebraska Act of 1854, D. The Missouri Compromise of 1820 Correct Option: None
Question 2: What was the main goal of the Missouri Compromise of 1820? Options: A. To abolish slavery in the United States, B. To balance the number of slave and free states in the Union, C. To establish the Republican Party, D. To create the Kansas and Nebraska territories Correct Option: None
Question 3: Who was the Democratic Senator from Illinois who introduced the Kansas-Nebraska Act? Options: A. Abraham Lincoln, B. Stephen A. Douglas, C. Alexander Stephens, D. John C. Fremont Correct Option: None
Question 4: What was the primary reason behind Stephen A. Douglas's introduction of the Kansas-Nebraska Act? Options: A. To abolish slavery in the United States, B. To promote the construction of a transcontinental railroad, C. To establish the Republican Party, D. To create the Kansas and Nebraska territories Correct Option: None
Question 5: What was the concept of "popular sovereignty" advocated by Stephen A. Douglas? Options: A. The idea that Congress should decide the status of slavery in a territory, B. The idea that the residents of a territory should decide the status of slavery, C. The idea that the President should decide the status of slavery in a territory, D. The idea that the Supreme Court should decide the status of slavery in a territory Correct Option: None
Question 6: What was the reaction of Northerners to the Kansas-Nebraska Act? Options: A. They were largely in favor of the act, B. They were neutral about the act, C. They were horrified and recognized it as repealing the Missouri Compromise, D. They were unaware of the act's implications Correct Option: None
Question 7: What was the outcome of the Kansas-Nebraska Act in terms of the national divide? Options: A. It united the nation behind a common cause, B. It had no significant impact on the national divide, C. It bitterly divided the nation, with 91% of the opposition coming from Northerners, D. It led to the immediate abolition of slavery Correct Option: None
Question 8: What was the impact of the Kansas-Nebraska Act on the Whig Party? Options: A. It strengthened the party and united its members, B. It had no significant impact on the party, C. It led to the party's irreparable split between Northern and Southern factions, D. It led to the party's immediate dissolution Correct Option: None
Question 9: Who was the first Republican presidential candidate, and what was the outcome of his election? Options: A. Abraham Lincoln, who won the election, B. John C. Fremont, who lost to Democrat James Buchanan, C. Stephen A. Douglas, who won the election, D. Alexander Stephens, who lost to Republican Abraham Lincoln Correct Option: None
Question 10: What was the ultimate outcome of the Kansas-Nebraska Act in terms of the nation's history? Options: A. It led to the immediate abolition of slavery, B. It united the nation behind a common cause, C. It made the Civil War much more likely, D. It had no significant impact on the nation's history Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that the most similar generated MCQ is:

**Question 2: What was the main goal of the Missouri Compromise of 1820?**

Although the question is not an exact match, it is related to the Missouri Compromise of 1820, which is the correct answer in the ground truth MCQ. However, none of the generated MCQs directly ask about the ban on slavery in the remaining Louisiana Purchase territory.

If I had to choose the most similar generated MCQ based on the content and intent, I would choose Question 2, but with the understanding that it's not a perfect match.

**Transcript**:
Today when people complain about the state of American politics, they often mention the dominance of the Democratic and Republican Parties, or the sharp split between red and blue states. But while it may seem like both of these things have been around forever, the situation looked quite different in 1850, with the Republican Party not yet existing, and support for the dominant Democrats and Whigs cutting across geographic divides. The collapse of this Second Party System was at the center of increasing regional tensions that would lead to the birth of the Republican Party, the rise of Abraham Lincoln as its leader, and a civil war that would claim over half a million lives. And if this collapse could be blamed on a single event, it would be the Kansas-Nebraska Act of 1854. The story starts with the Missouri Compromise of 1820. To balance the number of slave states and free states in the Union, it allowed slavery in the newly admitted state of Missouri, while making it off limits in the remaining federally administered Louisiana Territory. But compromises tend to last only as long as they're convenient, and by the early 1850s, a tenacious Democratic Senator from Illionis named Stephen A. Douglas found its terms very inconvenient. As an advocate of western expansion, he promoted constructing a transcontinental railroad across the Northern Plains with an eastern terminus in Chicago, where he happened to own real estate. For his proposal to succeed, Douglas felt that the territories through which the railroad passed, would have to be formally organized, which required the support of Southern politicians. He was also a believer in popular sovereignty, arguing that the status of slavery in a territory should be decided by its residents rather than Congress. So Douglas introduced a bill designed to kill two birds with one stone. While Douglas and his Southern supporters tried to frame the bill as protecting the political rights of settlers, horrified Northerners recognized it as repealing the 34-year-old Missouri Compromise and feared that its supporters' ultimate goal was to extend slavery to the entire nation. Congress was able to pass the Kansas-Nebraska Act, but at the huge cost of bitterly dividing the nation, with 91% of the opposition coming from Northerners. In the House of Representatives, politicians traded insults and brandished weapons until a Sargent at Arms restored order. President Pierce signed the bill into law amidst a storm of protest, while Georgia's Alexander Stephens, future Confederate Vice President, hailed the Act's passage as, "Glory enough for one day." The New York Tribune reported, "The unanimous sentiment of the North is indignant resistance." Douglas even admitted that he could travel from Washington D.C. to Chicago by the light of his own burning effigies. The political consequences of the Kansas-Nebraska Act were stunning. Previously, both Whigs and Democrats had included Northern and Southern lawmakers united around various issues, but now slavery became a dividing factor that could not be ignored. Congressmen from both parties spoke out against the act, including an Illinois Whig named Abraham Lincoln, denouncing "the monstrous injustice of slavery" in an 1854 speech. By this time the Whigs had all but ceased to exist, irreparably split between their Northern and Southern factions. In the same year, the new Republican Party was founded by the anti-slavery elements from both existing parties. Abraham Lincoln finally took up the Republican Party banner in 1856 and never looked back. That year, John C. And for that reason, it should be remembered as one of the most consequential pieces of legislation in American history.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Democrat Stephen A. Douglas sponsored what became known as the Kansas-Nebraska Act because ________.
Options: A. He opposed the expansion of slavery into western territories, B. He was a southerner, C. He was an abolitionist, D. He supported construction of a transcontinental railroad
Correct Option: D

**Transcript**:
Today when people complain about the state of American politics, they often mention the dominance of the Democratic and Republican Parties, or the sharp split between red and blue states. But while it may seem like both of these things have been around forever, the situation looked quite different in 1850, with the Republican Party not yet existing, and support for the dominant Democrats and Whigs cutting across geographic divides. But compromises tend to last only as long as they're convenient, and by the early 1850s, a tenacious Democratic Senator from Illionis named Stephen A. Douglas found its terms very inconvenient. Options: A. It repealed the time-honored Missouri Compromise, B. It provided for a transcontinental railroad along a southern route, C. It included the admission of two new slave states to the Union, D. Most were abolitionists by the 1850s
Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. **Transcript**:

Previously, both Whigs and Democrats had included Northern and Southern lawmakers united around various issues, but now slavery became a dividing factor that could not be ignored. Congressmen from both parties spoke out against the act, including an Illinois Whig named Abraham Lincoln, denouncing "the monstrous injustice of slavery" in an 1854 speech. By this time the Whigs had all but ceased to exist, irreparably split between their Northern and Southern factions. In the same year, the new Republican Party was founded by the anti-slavery elements from both existing parties. Although Lincoln still ran for Senate as a Whig in 1854, he was an early supporter of the new party, and helped to recruit others to its cause. Meanwhile the Democratic Party was shaken when events in the newly formed Kansas Territory revealed the violent consequences of popular sovereignty. Advertisements appeared across the North imploring people to emigrate to Kansas to stem the advance of slavery. The South answered with Border Ruffians, pro-slavery Missourians who crossed state lines to vote in fraudulent elections and raid anti-slavery settlements. One northern abolitionist, John Brown, became notorious following the Pottawatomie Massacre of 1856 when he and his sons hacked to death five pro-slavery farmers with broad swords. In the end, more than 50 people died in Bleeding Kansas. While nominally still a national party, Douglas's Democrats were increasingly divided along sectional lines, and many Northern members left to join the Republicans. Abraham Lincoln finally took up the Republican Party banner in 1856 and never looked back. That year, John C. Fremont, the first Republican presidential candidate, lost to Democrat, James Buchanan, but garnered 33% of the popular vote all from Northern states. Two years later, Lincoln challenged Douglas for his Illinois Senate seat, and although he lost that contest, it elevated his status among Republicans. Lincoln would finally be vindicated in 1860, when he was elected President of the United States, defeating in his own home state, a certain Northern Democrat, who was finally undone by the disastrous aftermath of the law he had masterminded. Americans today continue to debate whether the Civil War was inevitable, but there is no doubt that the Kansas-Nebraska Act made the ghastly conflict much more likely. And for that reason, it should be remembered as one of the most consequential pieces of legislation in American history.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Passage of the Kansas-Nebraska Act resulted in ________.
Options: A. Douglas's defeat in his re-election bid, B. The collapse of the already weakened Whig party, C. The disappearance of the Democratic party, D. The secession of several southern states
Correct Option: B

The idea that the Supreme Court should decide the status of slavery in a territory Correct Option: None

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Today when people complain about the state of American politics, they often mention the dominance of the Democratic and Republican Parties, or the sharp split between red and blue states. But while it may seem like both of these things have been around forever, the situation looked quite different in 1850, with the Republican Party not yet existing, and support for the dominant Democrats and Whigs cutting across geographic divides. The collapse of this Second Party System was at the center of increasing regional tensions that would lead to the birth of the Republican Party, the rise of Abraham Lincoln as its leader, and a civil war that would claim over half a million lives. And if this collapse could be blamed on a single event, it would be the Kansas-Nebraska Act of 1854. The story starts with the Missouri Compromise of 1820. To balance the number of slave states and free states in the Union, it allowed slavery in the newly admitted state of Missouri, while making it off limits in the remaining federally administered Louisiana Territory. But compromises tend to last only as long as they're convenient, and by the early 1850s, a tenacious Democratic Senator from Illionis named Stephen A. Douglas found its terms very inconvenient. As an advocate of western expansion, he promoted constructing a transcontinental railroad across the Northern Plains with an eastern terminus in Chicago, where he happened to own real estate. For his proposal to succeed, Douglas felt that the territories through which the railroad passed, would have to be formally organized, which required the support of Southern politicians. He was also a believer in popular sovereignty, arguing that the status of slavery in a territory should be decided by its residents rather than Congress. So Douglas introduced a bill designed to kill two birds with one stone. It would divide the large chunk of incorporated land into two new organized territories: Nebraska and Kansas, each of which would be open to slavery if the population voted to allow it. While Douglas and his Southern supporters tried to frame the bill as protecting the political rights of settlers, horrified Northerners recognized it as repealing the 34-year-old Missouri Compromise and feared that its supporters' ultimate goal was to extend slavery to the entire nation. Congress was able to pass the Kansas-Nebraska Act, but at the huge cost of bitterly dividing the nation, with 91% of the opposition coming from Northerners. In the House of Representatives, politicians traded insults and brandished weapons until a Sargent at Arms restored order. President Pierce signed the bill into law amidst a storm of protest, while Georgia's Alexander Stephens, future Confederate Vice President, hailed the Act's passage as, "Glory enough for one day." The New York Tribune reported, "The unanimous sentiment of the North is indignant resistance." Douglas even admitted that he could travel from Washington D.C. to Chicago by the light of his own burning effigies. The political consequences of the Kansas-Nebraska Act were stunning. Previously, both Whigs and Democrats had included Northern and Southern lawmakers united around various issues, but now slavery became a dividing factor that could not be ignored. Congressmen from both parties spoke out against the act, including an Illinois Whig named Abraham Lincoln, denouncing "the monstrous injustice of slavery" in an 1854 speech. By this time the Whigs had all but ceased to exist, irreparably split between their Northern and Southern factions. In the same year, the new Republican Party was founded by the anti-slavery elements from both existing parties. Although Lincoln still ran for Senate as a Whig in 1854, he was an early supporter of the new party, and helped to recruit others to its cause. Meanwhile the Democratic Party was shaken when events in the newly formed Kansas Territory revealed the violent consequences of popular sovereignty. Advertisements appeared across the North imploring people to emigrate to Kansas to stem the advance of slavery. The South answered with Border Ruffians, pro-slavery Missourians who crossed state lines to vote in fraudulent elections and raid anti-slavery settlements. One northern abolitionist, John Brown, became notorious following the Pottawatomie Massacre of 1856 when he and his sons hacked to death five pro-slavery farmers with broad swords. In the end, more than 50 people died in Bleeding Kansas. While nominally still a national party, Douglas's Democrats were increasingly divided along sectional lines, and many Northern members left to join the Republicans. Abraham Lincoln finally took up the Republican Party banner in 1856 and never looked back. That year, John C. Fremont, the first Republican presidential candidate, lost to Democrat, James Buchanan, but garnered 33% of the popular vote all from Northern states. Two years later, Lincoln challenged Douglas for his Illinois Senate seat, and although he lost that contest, it elevated his status among Republicans. Lincoln would finally be vindicated in 1860, when he was elected President of the United States, defeating in his own home state, a certain Northern Democrat, who was finally undone by the disastrous aftermath of the law he had masterminded. Americans today continue to debate whether the Civil War was inevitable, but there is no doubt that the Kansas-Nebraska Act made the ghastly conflict much more likely. And for that reason, it should be remembered as one of the most consequential pieces of legislation in American history.

Options: A. Drew support from many southerners, B. Was dedicated to a ban on the extension of slavery, C. Supported the Kansas-Nebraska Act, D. Enjoyed victory in the presidential election of 1856
Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 13, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Humans have been fascinated
with speed for ages. The history of human progress
is one of ever-increasing velocity, and one of the most important achievements
in this historical race was the breaking of the sound barrier. Not long after the first
successful airplane flights, pilots were eager to push
their planes to go faster and faster. But as they did so, increased turbulence and large forces on the plane
prevented them from accelerating further. Some tried to circumvent
the problem through risky dives, often with tragic results. Finally, in 1947, design improvements, such as a movable horizontal stabilizer,
the all-moving tail, allowed an American military pilot
named Chuck Yeager to fly the Bell X-1 aircraft at 1127 km/h, becoming the first person
to break the sound barrier and travel faster than the speed of sound. The Bell X-1 was the first of many
supersonic aircraft to follow, with later designs reaching
speeds over Mach 3. Aircraft traveling at supersonic speed
create a shock wave with a thunder-like noise
known as a sonic boom, which can cause distress to people
and animals below or even damage buildings. For this reason, scientists around the world
have been looking at sonic booms, trying to predict their path
in the atmosphere, where they will land,
and how loud they will be. To better understand
how scientists study sonic booms, let's start with some basics of sound. Imagine throwing a small stone
in a still pond. What do you see? The stone causes waves
to travel in the water at the same speed in every direction. These circles that keep growing in radius
are called wave fronts. Similarly, even though we cannot see it, a stationary sound source,
like a home stereo, creates sound waves traveling outward. The speed of the waves depends on factors like the altitude and temperature
of the air they move through. At sea level, sound travels
at about 1225 km/h. But instead of circles
on a two-dimensional surface, the wave fronts
are now concentric spheres, with the sound traveling along rays
perpendicular to these waves. Now imagine a moving sound source,
such as a train whistle. As the source keeps moving
in a certain direction, the successive waves in front of it
will become bunched closer together. This greater wave frequency is the cause
of the famous Doppler effect, where approaching objects
sound higher pitched. But as long as the source is moving
slower than the sound waves themselves, they will remain nested within each other. It's when an object goes supersonic,
moving faster than the sound it makes, that the picture changes dramatically. As it overtakes sound waves
it has emitted, while generating new ones from
its current position, the waves are forced together,
forming a Mach cone. No sound is heard
as it approaches an observer because the object is traveling faster
than the sound it produces. Only after the object has passed
will the observer hear the sonic boom. Where the Mach cone meets the ground,
it forms a hyperbola, leaving a trail known as the boom carpet
as it travels forward. This makes it possible to determine
the area affected by a sonic boom. What about figuring out how strong
a sonic boom will be? This involves solving the famous
Navier-Stokes equations to find the variation
of pressure in the air due to the supersonic aircraft
flying through it. This results in the pressure signature
known as the N-wave. What does this shape mean? Well, the sonic boom occurs
when there is a sudden change in pressure, and the N-wave involves two booms: one for the initial pressure rise
at the aircraft's nose, and another for when the tail passes, and the pressure suddenly
returns to normal. This causes a double boom, but it is usually heard as a single boom
by human ears. In practice, computer models
using these principles can often predict the location
and intensity of sonic booms for given atmospheric conditions
and flight trajectories, and there is ongoing research
to mitigate their effects. In the meantime, supersonic flight
over land remains prohibited. So, are sonic booms a recent creation? Not exactly. While we try to find ways to silence them, a few other animals have been
using sonic booms to their advantage. The gigantic Diplodocus may have been
capable of cracking its tail faster than sound, at over 1200 km/h,
possibly to deter predators. Some types of shrimp can also create
a similar shock wave underwater, stunning or even killing pray
at a distance with just a snap of their oversized claw. So while we humans
have made great progress in our relentless pursuit of speed, it turns out that nature was there first.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: If a train is travelling towards you, the train whistle sounds _____
Options: A. Louder, B. Softer, C. Higher pitched, D. Lower pitched
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is considered one of the most important achievements in human progress related to speed? Options: A. Reaching speeds over Mach 3, B. Breaking the sound barrier, C. Inventing the airplane, D. Developing the all-moving tail Correct Option: None
Question 2: Who was the first person to break the sound barrier in 1947? Options: A. Chuck Yeager's copilot, B. A British military pilot, C. Chuck Yeager, D. A scientist studying sonic booms Correct Option: None
Question 3: What is the name of the aircraft that Chuck Yeager flew to break the sound barrier? Options: A. Bell X-2, B. Bell X-1, C. Mach 3, D. Supersonic Jet Correct Option: None
Question 4: What is the term for the thunder-like noise created by an aircraft traveling at supersonic speed? Options: A. Sonic wave, B. Shock wave, C. Sonic boom, D. Mach cone Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the shape formed by the Mach cone when it meets the ground? Options: A. Circle, B. Hyperbola, C. Triangle, D. Square Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the name of the pressure signature that results from solving the Navier-Stokes equations? Options: A. N-wave, B. Sonic wave, C. Mach wave, D. Pressure wave Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the cause of the double boom in the N-wave pressure signature? Options: A. Initial pressure rise and final pressure drop, B. Initial pressure drop and final pressure rise, C. Initial pressure rise at the aircraft's nose and another when the tail passes, D. Initial pressure drop at the aircraft's nose and another when the tail passes Correct Option: None
Question 8: Why is supersonic flight over land currently prohibited? Options: A. Due to the high cost of supersonic aircraft, B. Due to the lack of technological advancements, C. Due to the potential damage caused by sonic booms, D. Due to the environmental impact of supersonic flight Correct Option: None
Question 9: Which animal may have been capable of creating a sonic boom to deter predators? Options: A. Diplodocus, B. Shrimp, C. Cheetah, D. Lion Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the speed at which sound travels at sea level? Options: A. 1000 km/h, B. 1127 km/h, C. 1225 km/h, D. 1200 km/h Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content, options, and overall intent. However, based on the topic of sound and its properties, the most similar generated MCQ is:

Question 10: What is the speed at which sound travels at sea level? Options: A. 1000 km/h, B. 1127 km/h, C. 1225 km/h, D. 1200 km/h

Although this question does not directly relate to the Doppler effect or the change in pitch when a train is approaching, it deals with the speed of sound, which is relevant to the context of the ground truth MCQ.

If I had to choose an index, I would say: 10

However, I would like to note that the generated MCQs do not directly address the concept of the Doppler effect or the change in pitch when a train is approaching, which is the main topic of the ground truth MCQ. A more accurate match would require a generated MCQ that specifically addresses this concept.

and animals below or even damage buildings. For this reason, scientists around the world

**Ground Truth MCQ**:

Options: A. Before a supersonic aircraft passes by, B. After a supersonic aircraft has passed by, C. When the speed of sound is 1127 km/h, D. When the speed of the aircraft is less than the speed of sound
Correct Option: B

However, a more relevant question related to the timing of sonic booms is not present among the generated MCQs. If I had to choose the most relevant generated MCQ based on the topic of sonic booms and their timing, I would suggest Question 7, which asks about the cause of the double boom in the N-wave pressure signature. This question is related to the phenomenon of sonic booms and provides some information about the pressure changes that occur when an aircraft breaks the sound barrier.

But since none of the questions directly match the ground truth MCQ, I will provide the index of the generated MCQ that is most closely related to the topic of sonic booms: 

 Question 7

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 13, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Humans have been fascinated
with speed for ages. The history of human progress
is one of ever-increasing velocity, and one of the most important achievements
in this historical race was the breaking of the sound barrier. Not long after the first
successful airplane flights, pilots were eager to push
their planes to go faster and faster. But as they did so, increased turbulence and large forces on the plane
prevented them from accelerating further. Some tried to circumvent
the problem through risky dives, often with tragic results. Finally, in 1947, design improvements, such as a movable horizontal stabilizer,
the all-moving tail, allowed an American military pilot
named Chuck Yeager to fly the Bell X-1 aircraft at 1127 km/h, becoming the first person
to break the sound barrier and travel faster than the speed of sound. The Bell X-1 was the first of many
supersonic aircraft to follow, with later designs reaching
speeds over Mach 3. Aircraft traveling at supersonic speed
create a shock wave with a thunder-like noise
known as a sonic boom, which can cause distress to people
and animals below or even damage buildings. For this reason, scientists around the world
have been looking at sonic booms, trying to predict their path
in the atmosphere, where they will land,
and how loud they will be. To better understand
how scientists study sonic booms, let's start with some basics of sound. Imagine throwing a small stone
in a still pond. What do you see? The stone causes waves
to travel in the water at the same speed in every direction. These circles that keep growing in radius
are called wave fronts. Similarly, even though we cannot see it, a stationary sound source,
like a home stereo, creates sound waves traveling outward. The speed of the waves depends on factors like the altitude and temperature
of the air they move through. At sea level, sound travels
at about 1225 km/h. But instead of circles
on a two-dimensional surface, the wave fronts
are now concentric spheres, with the sound traveling along rays
perpendicular to these waves. Now imagine a moving sound source,
such as a train whistle. As the source keeps moving
in a certain direction, the successive waves in front of it
will become bunched closer together. This greater wave frequency is the cause
of the famous Doppler effect, where approaching objects
sound higher pitched. But as long as the source is moving
slower than the sound waves themselves, they will remain nested within each other. It's when an object goes supersonic,
moving faster than the sound it makes, that the picture changes dramatically. As it overtakes sound waves
it has emitted, while generating new ones from
its current position, the waves are forced together,
forming a Mach cone. No sound is heard
as it approaches an observer because the object is traveling faster
than the sound it produces. Only after the object has passed
will the observer hear the sonic boom. Where the Mach cone meets the ground,
it forms a hyperbola, leaving a trail known as the boom carpet
as it travels forward. This makes it possible to determine
the area affected by a sonic boom. What about figuring out how strong
a sonic boom will be? This involves solving the famous
Navier-Stokes equations to find the variation
of pressure in the air due to the supersonic aircraft
flying through it. This results in the pressure signature
known as the N-wave. What does this shape mean? Well, the sonic boom occurs
when there is a sudden change in pressure, and the N-wave involves two booms: one for the initial pressure rise
at the aircraft's nose, and another for when the tail passes, and the pressure suddenly
returns to normal. This causes a double boom, but it is usually heard as a single boom
by human ears. In practice, computer models
using these principles can often predict the location
and intensity of sonic booms for given atmospheric conditions
and flight trajectories, and there is ongoing research
to mitigate their effects. In the meantime, supersonic flight
over land remains prohibited. So, are sonic booms a recent creation? Not exactly. While we try to find ways to silence them, a few other animals have been
using sonic booms to their advantage. The gigantic Diplodocus may have been
capable of cracking its tail faster than sound, at over 1200 km/h,
possibly to deter predators. Some types of shrimp can also create
a similar shock wave underwater, stunning or even killing pray
at a distance with just a snap of their oversized claw. So while we humans
have made great progress in our relentless pursuit of speed, it turns out that nature was there first.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: When is a sonic boom generated?
Options: A. When an object's speed exceeds the speed of sound it produces, B. When an object's speed is less than the speed of sound it produces, C. When the speed of sound is 1225 km/h, D. An aircraft flies
Correct Option: A

Question 4: What is the term for the thunder-like noise created by an aircraft traveling at supersonic speed? Options: A. Sonic wave, B. Shock wave, C. Sonic boom, D. Mach cone Correct Option: None
Question 5: What is the shape formed by the Mach cone when it meets the ground? Options: A. Circle, B. Hyperbola, C. Triangle, D. Square Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the name of the pressure signature that results from solving the Navier-Stokes equations? Options: A. N-wave, B. Sonic wave, C. Mach wave, D. Pressure wave Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the cause of the double boom in the N-wave pressure signature? Options: A. Initial pressure rise and final pressure drop, B. Initial pressure drop and final pressure rise, C. Initial pressure rise at the aircraft's nose and another when the tail passes, D. Initial pressure drop at the aircraft's nose and another when the tail passes Correct Option: None
Question 8: Why is supersonic flight over land currently prohibited? Options: A. Due to the high cost of supersonic aircraft, B. Due to the lack of technological advancements, C. Due to the potential damage caused by sonic booms, D. Due to the environmental impact of supersonic flight Correct Option: None
Question 9: Which animal may have been capable of creating a sonic boom to deter predators? Options: A. Diplodocus, B. Shrimp, C. Cheetah, D. Lion Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the speed at which sound travels at sea level? Options: A. 1000 km/h, B. 1127 km/h, C. 1225 km/h, D. 1200 km/h Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is not explicitly present in the provided options. However, based on the content and intent of the ground truth MCQ, the closest match can be inferred.

The ground truth MCQ asks, "When is a sonic boom generated?" with the correct option being "A. When an object's speed exceeds the speed of sound it produces." This question is related to the concept of sonic booms and their generation.

Among the provided generated MCQs, Question 4 is the closest match in terms of content and intent. It asks, "What is the term for the thunder-like noise created by an aircraft traveling at supersonic speed?" Although this question does not directly ask about the generation of sonic booms, it is related to the concept of sonic booms and their characteristics.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 13, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Humans have been fascinated
with speed for ages. The history of human progress
is one of ever-increasing velocity, and one of the most important achievements
in this historical race was the breaking of the sound barrier. Not long after the first
successful airplane flights, pilots were eager to push
their planes to go faster and faster. But as they did so, increased turbulence and large forces on the plane
prevented them from accelerating further. Some tried to circumvent
the problem through risky dives, often with tragic results. Finally, in 1947, design improvements, such as a movable horizontal stabilizer,
the all-moving tail, allowed an American military pilot
named Chuck Yeager to fly the Bell X-1 aircraft at 1127 km/h, becoming the first person
to break the sound barrier and travel faster than the speed of sound. The Bell X-1 was the first of many
supersonic aircraft to follow, with later designs reaching
speeds over Mach 3. Aircraft traveling at supersonic speed
create a shock wave with a thunder-like noise
known as a sonic boom, which can cause distress to people
and animals below or even damage buildings. For this reason, scientists around the world
have been looking at sonic booms, trying to predict their path
in the atmosphere, where they will land,
and how loud they will be. To better understand
how scientists study sonic booms, let's start with some basics of sound. Imagine throwing a small stone
in a still pond. What do you see? The stone causes waves
to travel in the water at the same speed in every direction. These circles that keep growing in radius
are called wave fronts. Similarly, even though we cannot see it, a stationary sound source,
like a home stereo, creates sound waves traveling outward. The speed of the waves depends on factors like the altitude and temperature
of the air they move through. At sea level, sound travels
at about 1225 km/h. But instead of circles
on a two-dimensional surface, the wave fronts
are now concentric spheres, with the sound traveling along rays
perpendicular to these waves. Now imagine a moving sound source,
such as a train whistle. As the source keeps moving
in a certain direction, the successive waves in front of it
will become bunched closer together. This greater wave frequency is the cause
of the famous Doppler effect, where approaching objects
sound higher pitched. But as long as the source is moving
slower than the sound waves themselves, they will remain nested within each other. It's when an object goes supersonic,
moving faster than the sound it makes, that the picture changes dramatically. As it overtakes sound waves
it has emitted, while generating new ones from
its current position, the waves are forced together,
forming a Mach cone. No sound is heard
as it approaches an observer because the object is traveling faster
than the sound it produces. Only after the object has passed
will the observer hear the sonic boom. Where the Mach cone meets the ground,
it forms a hyperbola, leaving a trail known as the boom carpet
as it travels forward. This makes it possible to determine
the area affected by a sonic boom. What about figuring out how strong
a sonic boom will be? This involves solving the famous
Navier-Stokes equations to find the variation
of pressure in the air due to the supersonic aircraft
flying through it. This results in the pressure signature
known as the N-wave. What does this shape mean? Well, the sonic boom occurs
when there is a sudden change in pressure, and the N-wave involves two booms: one for the initial pressure rise
at the aircraft's nose, and another for when the tail passes, and the pressure suddenly
returns to normal. This causes a double boom, but it is usually heard as a single boom
by human ears. In practice, computer models
using these principles can often predict the location
and intensity of sonic booms for given atmospheric conditions
and flight trajectories, and there is ongoing research
to mitigate their effects. In the meantime, supersonic flight
over land remains prohibited. So, are sonic booms a recent creation? Not exactly. While we try to find ways to silence them, a few other animals have been
using sonic booms to their advantage. The gigantic Diplodocus may have been
capable of cracking its tail faster than sound, at over 1200 km/h,
possibly to deter predators. Some types of shrimp can also create
a similar shock wave underwater, stunning or even killing pray
at a distance with just a snap of their oversized claw. So while we humans
have made great progress in our relentless pursuit of speed, it turns out that nature was there first.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The speed of sound depends on:
Options: A. Temperature, B. The speed of the aircraft, C. Direction, D. The type of the sound source
Correct Option: A

Question 5: What is the shape formed by the Mach cone when it meets the ground? Options: A. Circle, B. Hyperbola, C. Triangle, D. Square Correct Option: None
Question 6: What is the name of the pressure signature that results from solving the Navier-Stokes equations? Options: A. N-wave, B. Sonic wave, C. Mach wave, D. Pressure wave Correct Option: None
Question 7: What is the cause of the double boom in the N-wave pressure signature? Options: A. Initial pressure rise and final pressure drop, B. Initial pressure drop and final pressure rise, C. Initial pressure rise at the aircraft's nose and another when the tail passes, D. Initial pressure drop at the aircraft's nose and another when the tail passes Correct Option: None
Question 8: Why is supersonic flight over land currently prohibited? Options: A. Due to the high cost of supersonic aircraft, B. Due to the lack of technological advancements, C. Due to the potential damage caused by sonic booms, D. Due to the environmental impact of supersonic flight Correct Option: None
Question 9: Which animal may have been capable of creating a sonic boom to deter predators? Options: A. Diplodocus, B. Shrimp, C. Cheetah, D. Lion Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the speed at which sound travels at sea level? Options: A. 1000 km/h, B. 1127 km/h, C. 1225 km/h, D. 1200 km/h Correct Option: None

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 13, Question 5
